intro: Commiphora campestris subsp. wajirensis, commonly known as the Wajirensis myrrh tree, is a small to medium-sized shrub or tree native to parts of East Africa. It belongs to the Burseraceae family and is characterized by its aromatic resinous exudates, which are used in traditional medicine and incense. The plant typically grows in dry, rocky soils and is adapted to arid and semi-arid environments. Its leaves are alternate, simple, and often have a rough texture, while its flowers are small and clustered. The subspecies is distinguished by its unique morphological features and geographic distribution compared to other Commiphora species.
